head.title: One Man's Windfall, One Industry's Gyration

hedline.hl1: One Man's Windfall, One Industry's Gyration

block.p: Re your April 2 front-page article on the proposed merger of U.S. Healthcare, a leader in managed health care, and Aetna Life and Casualty Company, which will result in the nation's largest medical benefits company:

Re your April 2 front-page article on the proposed merger of U.S. Healthcare, a leader in managed health care, and Aetna Life and Casualty Company, which will result in the nation's largest medical benefits company:
With the merger, Leonard Abramson, the founder, chairman and controlling shareholder of U.S. Healthcare, will receive about $750 million in cash and Aetna stock.
That sum equals what U.S. Healthcare will pay its primary care physicians to treat and care for all of its subscribers for three years!

This money was extracted from the system by reducing payments to everyone involved in the medical industry. Now Mr. Abramson says that the merger is needed to force further reductions in the charges of hospitals and physicians.

The creation of a system that allows an individual to accumulate so much wealth -- not by providing care but simply by shifting charges -- makes one reflect on the future of American medicine and managed care.
ROSS E. MC RONALD , M.D. Brick, N.J., April 3, 1996
